Co/Hydroxyapatite catalysts for N2O catalytic decomposition: Design of well-defined active sites with geometrical and spacing effects Yongzhao Wang Conceptualization Methodology Writing - review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition a * Xiang Zhou Conceptualization Methodology Formal analysis Investigation Writing - original draft Writing - review & editing a b Xuhui Wei Conceptualization Methodology Investigation a b Xiao Li Methodology Investigation a b Ruifang Wu Investigation Formal analysis a Xiaobo Hu Investigation Formal analysis a b Yongxiang Zhao Conceptualization Methodology Writing - review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition a a Engineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals, Shanxi University, China Engineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals Shanxi University China Engineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals, Shanxi University b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanxi University, Taiyuan, 030006, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shanxi University Taiyuan 030006 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanxi University, Taiyuan, 030006, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Different methods including ion exchange, impregnation and hydrothermal method were used to prepare Co/hydroxyapatite catalysts with various Co species. The catalytic activities for N2O decomposition were studied. It was concluded that Co2+ ⅡOh existed in Co(1.2)-IE prepared by ion exchange is more active than Co2+Td, Co3+Oh and Co2+ Ⅰ obtained by impregnation and hydrothermal methods, respectively. Meanwhile, Co(1.2)-IE shows better stability and stronger resistance against 2.0 vol.% O2 or 2.3 vol.% H2O in the feed gas. The higher catalytic activity of Co2+ ⅡOh is attributed to its octahedral coordination geometrical structure, which make Co2+ ⅡOh tend to donate electrons to activate N2O. Furthermore, the closer spacing distance between two Co2+ ⅡOh sites can facilitate the combination and desorption of oxygen species. The above mentioned reasons ultimately lead to the increased catalytic activity. Finally, the results of density functional theory calculations indicate that the Co2+ ⅡOh possesses the highest d-band center, which means the excellent catalytic activity. Keywords Co/Hydroxyapatite N2O catalytic decomposition Active sites Geometrical effects Spacing effects 1 Introduction In the field of environmental pollution abatement, N2O has been recognized as one of the most important greenhouse gases. The global warming potential of N2O is 310 times higher than that of CO2 and it has a long lifetime about 150 years [1–3]. Moreover, the ozone layer in the atmosphere can be seriously destroyed by N2O. In recent years, the atmospheric concentration of N2O still greatly increases at about 0.25 % annually, which primarily is due to the anthropogenic industry, e.g. the production of nitric acid and adipic acid [4]. One of the prospective methods for elimination of N2O is catalytic decomposition, and many kinds of catalysts such as noble metals [5,6], metal oxides [7–10], and ion-exchanged zeolites [11,12] have been studied. Among metal oxides, Co3O4 metal oxides have been considered as potential materials for the N2O catalytic decomposition owing to the relatively higher catalytic performances and economically favorable price [7–10]. For further enhancing the catalytic activity of Co3O4 catalysts, Co3O4-based catalysts have been extensively studied via surface or bulk modification of alkali metals, rare earth metals or transition metals elements [13–15]. For instance, Yan et al. [14] investigated the Co3O4 catalysts with bulk modification by Ni and Mg for N2O catalytic decomposition. The results have demonstrated that Ni2+ or Mg2+ can interact with Co2+, which has not been completely replaced, and this operation can lead to the increased catalytic activity. Similarly, Yu and co-authors [15] studied the Co-Ag catalysts with surface modification by Ag for N2O catalytic decomposition. Interestingly, the Co-O bond of the Co-Ag catalysts is significantly weakened and more oxygen vacancies are generated due to presence of Ag. Thus the surface oxygen species are easier to desorb, which are conducive to the regeneration of active sites and promoted catalytic activity. However, since the N2O catalytic decomposition is a gas-solid two-phase reaction, a large amount of the bulk phase active component can not be fully utilized, leading to the low atom efficiency. At the same time, high-dose use will undoubtedly increase the cost of the catalyst, which is not conducive to large scale application of industrial production. In order to maximize the catalytic efficiency of metals and reduce the manufacturing cost, a solid catalyst with maximum atom efficiency has become the primary choice of researchers [16,17]. Meanwhile, the active sites for N2O catalytic decomposition on Co3O4 or Co-based catalysts are still controversial. It is well known that Co3O4 possesses the typical spinel structure [18], in which the tetrahedral Co2+ (Co2+Td) and octahedral Co3+ (Co3+Oh) are simultaneously present. To address this problem, in recent years a lot of researches have been conducted on Co-based catalysts for N2O decomposition to investigate the real active sites. Won-Hyun et al. [19] studied the Co3O4 and its reduced forms (CoO or CoxOy) for N2O decomposition. It turned out that not Co3O4 itself but its reduced forms are active, which have more amounts of Co2+ than Co3O4. Consequently, Co2+ is deemed the active site. Stelmachowski et al. [18] studied a series of cobalt spinels with redox Co2+ and Co3+ cations replaced by non-redox Mg2+ and Al3+ cations, respectively. It was shown that, the replacing Co3+ with Al3+ resulted in a greater decrease in catalytic activity compared to Mg2+ replacing Co2+, and it in turn proved that Co3+ was identified as active site. Moreover, Wang et al. [20] prepared the Pb0.04Co catalyst by the co-precipitation method and investigated the N2O decomposition. Surprisingly, the addition of Pb into the catalyst obviously increases the SBET and the amounts of Co2+ on the catalyst, and then enhances the catalytic activity. Therefore, Co2+ is considered to be the active center. Additionally, Zhang et al. [21] prepared a serial of CoxTi catalysts for N2O catalytic decomposition. The Co0.6Ti catalyst shows better catalytic stability compared with the Co3O4 catalyst due to its stronger structural stability, and it has caused more surface Co3+ species, which are considered as the significant active sites for N2O catalytic activity. Consequently, in terms of theoretical research, clarifying the intrinsic roles of various types of cobalt sites remains a challenging work. More importantly, understanding the nature of active sites can provide guidance for the accurate design of efficient catalysts. As a porous carrier, hydroxyapatite (HAP, Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2) presents various advantages including moderate acidity and alkalinity, high physical and thermal stability, as well as low price [22,23]. In addition, surface OH− and PO4 3- groups are able to stabilize the structure of active sites, and the acid-base properties can be adjusted via changing Ca/P ratio. Moreover, the Ca2+, PO4 3- and/or OH- of hydroxyapatite allow cation and anion exchanging because of the existence of two kinds of zeolite-like channels, thus which could modify the chemical properties without destroying the characteristic hexagonal structure [24]. The first kind of channel (Scheme 1 ) possesses a diameter of approximate 0.25 nm and includes Ca2+ ions (Ca2+ Ⅰ), coordinated by 9 oxygen atoms forming a polyhedron (c-axis). The second kind of channel (0.35 nm in diameter) contains Ca2+ Ⅱ cations, surrounded by 5 oxygen atoms and an OH− forming an octahedron [25]. Thus, HAP has been used as supports to prepare catalysts for selective hydrogenation [26,27] or oxidation [28,29] of organic substrates, CO oxidation [30,31], and hydrogen generation [32,33]. HAP has been already used in the de-N2O system. For instance, Ma et al. [34] found that Rh/HAP showed much higher activity for N2O decomposition compared with conventional Rh/TiO2, Rh/Al2O3, and Rh/SiO2 catalysts, which is ascribed to the better basicity of the HAP support and high dispersion of rhodium species on HAP. In another of their works [35], the author prepared HAP supports by hydrothermal methods at 200 or 100 ℃ in the presence of PEG or EDTA additive, and the supported rhodium catalysts were obtained. It was found that after modification the HAP-PEG-200 support showed more rod-like structures and more amouts of basic sites. And the Rh/HAP-PEG-200 exhibited significantly higher activity than the Rh/HAP-normal. Our research group has reported that the Co3O4 supported on bone-derived natural HAP showed excellent catalytic activity for N2O decomposition [36]. However, the discussion on the active sites of Co/HAP catalysts is still unclear, which needs to be further explored. At this work, HAP was used as the support to prepare Co/HAP catalysts. Based on the structural characteristics of HAP, a series of Co species active sites with different coordination environments were designed and constructed by impregnation, ion exchange and hydrothermal methods, respectively. By investigating the catalytic activity and stability for N2O decomposition and combining with XRD, TEM, N2-physisorption, ICP, FT-IR, UV–vis, CO2-TPD, H2-TPR, XPS characterization techniques and DFT calculation, the catalysts with high catalytic activity and high efficiency of Co atom were obtained, and the catalytic nature was also elucidated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of samples According to the relevant literatures [37,38], the Ca/P ratio of catalysts prepared by the ion exchange method using HAP as a carrier will decrease, accompanied by the decrease of alkalinity, which will affect the N2O catalytic decomposition activity. In order to eliminate the effect of preparation methods on the basicity of catalysts, the preparation process is as follows： HAP-1 support: a solution of (NH4)2HPO4 (0.6 mol L−1) was added drop-wise to that of Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (1 mol L−1) under stirring. The resulting precipitate was slowly dissolved in nitric acid (2 mol L−1). Then, the solution was adjusted to pH = 9 by adding ammonia which led to the second precipitation, and the pH was maintained while stirring at 80 °C for 8 h. After filtration, the recovered solid was washed well with distilled water, and then dried at 120 °C for 12 h and calcined at 600 °C in air for 2 h. HAP-2 support: a solution of (NH4)2HPO4 (0.74 mol L−1) was added drop-wise to that of Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (1 mol L−1) while stirring. The next operations are the same as the preparation processes of HAP-1 support. Ion exchange method: 10 g of HAP-1 was added into 1 L of aqueous solution containing 2 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O. The mixture was stirred continuously for 36 h. Then the solid recovered after filtration was washed several times, dried at 140 °C for 12 h and finally calcined at 550 °C for 3 h. The sample gained was signed as Co(1.2)-IE. Impregnation method: 0.5397 g or 2.3388 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 3.6 mL of distilled water, and then 9 g of HAP-2 were added into the above solution. The impregnated samples were dried in air at 140 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 550 °C for 3 h. The samples obtained were assigned as Co(1.2)-IM and Co(5.0)-IM, respectively. Hydrothermal method: 300 mL of aqueous solution including Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1.1148 g), (NH4)2HPO4 (2.5665 g) and Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (7.0517 g) was prepared. The pH of the solution was modified to 9 via the addition of NH3·H2O, which was holded while stirring at 40 °C at least 8 h. Then the suspension solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined auto-clave and heated at 110 °C for 6 h. The solid recovered after filtration was washed with distilled water several times, and then dried at 140 °C for 12 h and finally calcined at 600 °C for 3 h. The sample obtained was assigned as Co(7.0)-HT. 2.2 Catalyst characterization and tests procedure The characterization and catalytic tests procedure of the catalysts were exactly same as those described in our previous publications [39,7]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations performed with the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) using Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) for exchange correlation energy were used to investigate the d-band centers. The more detailed information of DFT calculation can be found in the supporting information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization To determine the composition of HAP supports and Co/HAP catalysts, Co, Ca and P contents of the samples were assayed by ICP-AES. As shown in the second column of Table 1 , the actual Co contents of Co(1.2)-IE, Co(1.2)-IM, Co(5.0)-IM and Co(7.0)-HT are 1.20, 1.15, 5.81 and 6.29 wt.%, respectively. In addition, the Ca/P molar ratios of the samples were also determined, for expected, all catalysts have the similar Ca/P molar ratio. Simultaneously, from the CO2-TPD results (Figure S1 and Table S1), it was indicated that the total basic site amounts of these four catalysts are relatively close to each other, which are consisted with the Ca/P ratio. Furthermore, the texture properties dates of samples are shown in Table 1 measured by N2-physisorption (Figure S2). Although these catalysts were prepared by different preparation methods, the similar data of SBET, pore size and pore volume show that there is no significant difference in their textural properties. XRD results are shown in Fig. 1 . It can be noticed that XRD patterns of both HAP supports are consistent with the standard pattern of HAP (JCPDS No. 09-0432). For the Co(5.0)-IM catalyst, some extra diffraction peaks observed are not belong to the HAP-2. These peaks appearing at 2θ = 31.6° and 37° are assigned to the Co3O4 with spinel structure (JCPDS No. 43-1003), which are consistent with FT-IR results (Figure S3). In addition, the XRD patterns of Co(1.2)-IM as well as Co(1.2)-IE do not display peaks of Co3O4 crystals indicating that: in one case the high dispersion and small crystallite size, or in the other case Co2+ replacing Ca2+ into HAP structure. In addition, besides the lower intensity of HAP characteristic peaks, the XRD pattern of Co(7.0)-HT shows some extra peaks at 2θ = 22.1, 32.7, 34.6, 44.9 and 47.3°, which can be attributed to the characteristic peaks of Ca19Co2(PO4)14 (PDF#49-1081). The formation of Ca19Co2(PO4)14 is probably caused by the substituting of Co2+ for Ca2+ Ⅰ, which can play a role in the HAP to stabilize its structure [40]. Furthermore, the average sizes of HAP crystallites are calculated according to Scherrer equation for HAP-1, HAP-2, Co(1.2)-IE, Co(1.2)-IM, Co(5.0)-IM and Co(7.0)-HT, which are 52, 68, 65, 58, 68, and 53 nm (Table 1), respectively. Simultaneously, the average size of Co3O4 crystallite for Co(5.0)-IM is 21 nm, which is consistent with TEM result (will be presented shortly). Fig. 2 a-c give TEM images of the Co(1.2)-IE, Co(1.2)-IM and Co(5.0)-IM catalysts. It can be seen that the morphologies of the HAP supports show a kind of homologous rod structure, and the crystallites sizes are consisted with the XRD results. The Co(1.2)-IE, Co(1.2)-IM, and Co(5.0)-IM catalysts were further investigated by HRTEM in order to estimate the morphologies as well as crystallites size of Co species. On the Co(1.2)-IE catalyst (Fig. 2d) the well defined lattice fringes can be evidently observed, and the measured spacing is about 0.8 nm, which is ascribed to (100) lattice plane of HAP. Notably, some dark areas on the HAP were also observed, which may be interrelated with channels formed by well crystallized HAP plane. Examination of Co(1.2)-IM and Co(5.0)-IM micrographs reveal some different areas, which have been not observed on the Co(1.2)-IE. For the Co(5.0)-IM, there is a relatively large Co species, ranging from 18 to 22 nm, which possesses a quasi-spherical shape. The measured distance of lattice fringe is approximately 0.46 nm, which is ascribed to (111) lattice plane of Co3O4. Meanwhile, some smaller Co particles ranging from 6 to 10 nm have been observed on the Co(1.2)-IM, and the lattice fringes are not clear, which mean that the formation of Co species are different from Co3O4. Thus, it can be concluded that different preparation methods and Co contents lead to different forms of Co species presented on HAP. HAADF-STEM and EDX elemental mapping images showed in Fig. 3 and Figure S4 provide the morphological features and an overview of the dispersion of the Ca, P, O and Co elements of Co(1.2)-IE and Co(1.2)-IM catalysts, respectively. The element mapping of Co(1.2)-IE (Fig. 3) reveals that all element signals had similar shapes and locations in the HAADF-STEM image, which offers convincing evidence that elements Ca, P, O and Co are homogeneously dispersed in the Co(1.2)-IE sample. It is not surprising that the dispersion of Co element on Co(1.2)-IE is better than Co(1.2)-IM (Figure S4). These results are consistent with the XRD and (HR)-TEM results discussed above. Fig. 4 shows UV–vis spectra of Co/HAP. Within UV regions of all samples, there is a band at around 251 nm, which belongs to the O2−→Ca2+ charge transfers of HAP support [41]. For the Co(1.2)-IE, the spectrum shows three d-d transition bands at 510, 569, and 638 nm. Similar spectra were obtained in the literatures [42,43]. For example, Verberckmoes and co-authors [42] reported that the three d-d transition bands could be attributed to ʋ3≡4T1g(F)→4T1g(P) and ʋ1≡4T1g(F)→4T2g transitions of the six-coordinated octahedral Co2+ located at cation exchange sites in the ZSM-5 (Figure S5). Hence, it can be concluded that, for Co(1.2)-IE, the exchanged Co2+ is possibly located at the octahedral site, that is, the position of Ca2+ Ⅱ. The same bands at 510, 570, and 640 nm are also observed on the spectra of Co(7.0)-HT and Co(1.2)-IM (weak bands), indicating that the two catalysts also contain the Co2+ located at the octahedral site, which are identical to TPR results (will be shown soon). On the other hand, the spectrum of Co(5.0)-IM shows a similar feature with that of the bulk Co3O4 (Figure S6). The band at 670 nm can be ascribed to ʋ2≡4A2→4T1(P) transition, which corresponds to tetrahedral Co2+ [43]. Likewise, the transition bands at 749 and 351−461 nm indicate the existence of octahedral Co3+, which are related with ʋ1≡1A1g→1T1g and ʋ2≡1A1g→1T2g, respectively [43]. By contrast, compared with Co(5.0)-IM, the UV–vis peak of Co(1.2)-IM becomes shorter due to the low Co content, and the peak at 433 nm shifts to 400 nm, suggesting the formation of non-well crystallized Co3O4 on the Co(1.2)-IM, which can also be judged by the color of the samples. (Figure S7). H2-TPR profiles are shown in Fig. 5 . It can been seen that there are no reduction peak on the two HAP supports. So, all the H2 consumption peaks are ascribed to the reduction of Co species. The profile of Co(5.0)-IM is characterized by the existence of two typical reduction peaks of Co3O4 (α and β areas) in the temperature range of 310−500 °C, and the peak at high temperature (>550 °C, γ area) can be ascribed to the reduction of exchanged Co2+ ions. Generally, the reduction process of Co3O4 can be divided into two steps—the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ (α area) and that of Co2+ to Co(β area) [20]. As to the Co(1.2)-IM, the TPR profile is similar to that of Co(5.0)-IM, but the reduction peak area of the Co3+ ions to Co2+ (α area) is relatively smaller. Furthermore, the ratio of Co2+/Co3+ at the α and β areas was computed by the amounts of hydrogen consumed. As shown in the seventh column of Table S2, the value of Co2+/Co3+ is about 3.06 on the Co(5.0)-IM catalyst, which is closes to that of stoichiometric Co3O4 (3.00). However, for the Co(1.2)-IM the value of Co2+/Co3+ (6.00) is much higher indicating the formation of non-stoichiometric Co3O4 (CoxOy), which are identical to HRTEM and UV–vis results. Interestingly, Co(1.2)-IE and Co(7.0)-HT catalysts do not present any reduction peaks associated with Co3O4, but show reduction peaks at higher temperature (γ and δ area), which are caused by exchanged Co2+. In light of the special structure of HAP, i.e. the existence of CaI and CaII sites, and the different preparation methods, the CaII ions in the c-axis oriented channel are more easily to be substituted during the ion exchange process. Simultaneously, according to the UV–vis results, the Co2+ Ⅱ ion occupies the octahedral site (Co2+ ⅡOh). Thus, the peak at about 730 °C (γ area) can be ascribed to Co2+ ⅡOh replaced CaⅡ. The peak at 801 °C (δ area) observed only for Co(7.0)-HT is attributed to Co2+ Ⅰ ions located at CaⅠ sites due to the formation of Ca19Co2(PO4)14 appearing in the XRD result. It is worth mentioning that there is a small peak (γ area) at around 700 °C on the TPR profiles of the impregnated Co/HAP catalysts, which demonstrate the presence of exchanged Co2+ ⅡOh species. It indicates that the ion exchange process will inevitably occur during the impregnation process, which is in accord with previous reports [44] and our UV–vis results. The surface cobalt species of Co(1.2)-IE, Co(1.2)-IM, Co(5.0)-IM, and Co(7.0)-HT have been studied via XPS technique. Fig. 6 summarizes the relevant results. For Co(1.2)-IM and Co(5.0)-IM, the Co2p3/2 spectra of Co species can be fitted with Co2+ (u) and Co3+ (v) according to BE at around 782.5 and 780.7 eV, respectively [40,45]. The shake-up satellite peak (m) emerging at 787.7 eV indicates the presence of Co2+ [43]. Here, the ratios of Co2+/Co3+ calculated based on the fitting results are displayed in Table S3, which are 0.51 and 1.04 for Co(5.0)-IM and Co(1.2)-IM, respectively. It indicates that the amount of surface Co2+ of CoxOy increase compared with that of Co3O4. In the Co2p3/2 region, the XPS spectra for the Co(1.2)-IE and Co(7.0)-HT catalysts exhibit two peaks, centred at 782.2 (u) and 787.2 (m) eV, which can be attributed to exchanged Co2+ ⅡOh or Co2+ Ⅰ as well as its satellite peak, respectively. What merits our attention is that the u peak (Co2+ ⅡOh) position of the Co(1.2)-IE shifts to lower BE (from 782.6 or 782.4 to 782.3 eV), compared to those of the two impregnated Co/HAP catalysts, suggesting that the Co2+ ⅡOh substituted for Ca2+ Ⅱ is more electron-rich than Co2+ of the Co3O4 or CoxOy [8,46]. In addition, the u peak (Co2+ Ⅰ) shifts to lower binding energy for the Co(7.0)-HT (from 782.4 eV to 782.1 eV) compared with that of Co(1.2)-IE. It indicates that Co2+ Ⅰ is more electron-rich than Co2+ ⅡOh, which may be attributed to the higher coordination number (9) of Co2+ Ⅰ than that of Co2+ ⅡOh. 3.2 Catalytic testing The N2O conversions over the HAP and Co/HAP are shown in Fig. 7 . N2O decomposition begins at nearly 460 °C on Co(1.2)-IM, and the conversion of N2O is only 60 % at 600 °C. As to Co(1.2)-IE, T50 is about 510 °C, and the conversion of N2O is 95 % at 600 °C, which is much higher than that of Co(1.2)-IM under the same reaction conditions. As for Co(5.0)-IM and Co(7.0)-HT catalysts, higher catalytic activity have been achieved. Due to the difference of Co contents of these catalysts, the specific reaction rates r at different temperatures (Table S4) and the corresponding activation energy (Ea) (Table S5 and Figure S8) were calculated. As shown in Table S4, Co(1.2)-IE, Co(1.2)-IM, Co(5.0)-IM, and Co(7.0)-HT show the specific reaction rates of 5.25, 1.86, 1.57, and 1.27 μmols−1 g−1 at the 520 °C, respectively. It is noteworthy that the r of Co(1.2)-IE is 2.84 times higher than that of Co(1.2)-IM. Furthermore, the activation energy on Co(1.2)-IE in Table S5 and Figure S8 is only 84.22 kJ mol-1, which is significantly lower than that of other catalysts. About N2O catalytic decomposition, major researchers focused on the catalytic reaction only under ideal reaction conditions. However, various inhibitors (H2O, O2, etc.) are unavoidably coexisting in sweep gas. Hence, Fig. 8 shows the results of N2O decomposition under the conditions of 0.1 vol.% N2O/Ar together with 2 vol.% O2 or 2.3 vol.% H2O as well. It is clearly seen that the addition of O2 inhibits the catalytic activity to varying degrees. As mentioned earlier [7], N2O decomposition usually can be inhibited by O2, because O2 can make the balance of Equation (O* + O* → O2* → O2 + *) to shift left and hinder O* desorption. For Co(1.2)-IM, the N2O conversion profile shifts to higher temperature about 35 °C at 41 % of N2O conversion due to the presence of O2, while that is only about 14 °C for Co(1.2)-IE. Therefore, although both catalytic activities are inhibited by O2, Co(1.2)-IE is of relatively high resistance to O2 in the same Co content and reaction conditions. Obviously, as shown in Fig. 8, the catalytic activities are evidently inhibited by the addition of H2O for both catalysts. According to the reports [47,48], DFT calculations about (010) and (001) of HAP surfaces demonstrated the high affinity to H2O. So it can be speculated that H2O molecule will compete with the N2O molecule at the surface active site of the catalyst, resulting in a decrease of catalytic activity. Hence, the N2O conversion was about 95 % and 62 % over Co(1.2)-IE and Co(1.2)-IM at 600 °C without H2O, however in the presence of H2O, it declined to 78 % and 31 %, respectively. Obviously, the influence of H2O on N2O decomposition over Co(1.2)-IE is smaller than that over Co(1.2)-IM. The catalytic stability of Co(1.2)-IM and Co(1.2)-IE for N2O decomposition was studied at 600 ℃. As shown in Fig. 9 , Co(1.2)-IM shows inferior catalytic stability and the initial catalytic activity (about 61 %) decreases slowly with time on stream. However, for Co(1.2)-IE, the N2O conversion can maintain at around 95 % for 30 h. Obviously, Co(1.2)-IE exhibits comparatively more excellent catalytic activity and stability than Co(1.2)-IM. In additon, Co(1.2)-HT catalyst was also prepared and tested the activity and stability for N2O decomposition, which are given in Figure S14 and S15. As expected, Co(1.2)-HT shows the poorest catalytic performance among the three catalysts with the same Co contents. To understand the origin about the better catalytic activity of Co(1.2)-IE and the inactivation of Co(1.2)-IM, the used Co/HAP samples after 30 h were measured via XRD (Figure S9), N2-physisorption (Table 1), TEM (Figure S10), H2-TPR (Figure S11), and XPS (Figure S12). The results indicate that the texture properties of the catalysts do not change significantly after use. However, for the Co(1.2)-IM-Used, the Co2+/Co3+ ratio of CoxOy species decrease (H2-TPR and XPS), while larger and more amount of Co particles are observed on the TEM image, which may be due to the aggregation and crystallization of CoxOy clusters. All of these results indicate that in order to maintain the dispersion of Co species under operating conditions and then sustain catalytic activity, metal atoms or ions can be anchored to the support via covalent bonds with oxygen atoms in the catalyst support [49,50]. According to the XRD results, Co3O4 is observed only on the Co(5.0)-IM sample, which is also confirmed by TEM, FT-IR, and UV–vis results. At the same time, the H2-TPR results show that the Co(5.0)-IM mainly contains the stoichiometric Co3O4 and a small amount of ion exchange Co2+ Ⅱ, however, there are mainly non-stoichiometric Co3O4 and small portions of ion exchange Co2+ Ⅱ formed on the Co(1.2)-IM catalyst. The non-stoichiometric Co3O4 is considered to the CoxOy cluster composed of a mixture of more Co2+ and less Co3+(Co2+/Co3+ = 6.00) compared with stoichiometric Co3O4 (Co2+/Co3+ = 3.00), which is in-line with the XPS result. Moreover, the Co(1.2)-IE consists mainly of Co2+ Ⅱ, which substituted for the Ca2+ Ⅱ in the HAP channel during ion exchange. Meanwhile, UV–vis results show that Co2+ Ⅱ occupies an octahedral site (Co2+ ⅡOh) and is more electron-rich than Co2+ of tetrahedral coordination (Co2+Td), which is confirmed by XPS results. Nevertheless, for the Co(7.0)-HT the main Co species are Co2+ Ⅰ substituted for the CaⅠ as well as a small amount of Co2+ ⅡOh, and their contents are calculated according the amount of H2 consumption, which are 83 % and 17 %, respectively (Table S2). Combined with the specific activities of catalysts: Co(1.2)-IE > Co(1.2)-IM > Co(5.0)-IM > Co(7.0)-HT, it can be concluded that Co2+ Ⅱ occupying an octahedral site (Co2+ Ⅱ Oh) is the dominating active center for N2O catalytic decomposition. At the same time, the Co(1.2)-IM with the main composition of CoxOy species possessing more Co2+Td shows the higher specific activity than the Co(5.0)-IM, which have more Co3+. So, it is considered that Co2+Td possesses higher catalytic activity than Co3+. Besides, Co(7.0)-HT mainly containing Co2+ Ⅰ shows the lowest specific activity. In order to further understand the effects of the amount of Co2+ ⅡOh species on the catalytic decomposition activity of N2O, the relevance of the specific reaction activity and the relative proportion of Co2+ ⅡOh was established in the Fig. 10 . Here, the ratio of Co2+ ⅡOh is calculated by Co2+ ⅡOh/Co species according to the amount of H2 consumption. It is clear that the catalytic decomposition activity of N2O rises substantially as the ratio of Co2+ Ⅱ increases. It can be clearly seen that Co2+ ⅡOh plays the most significant role for N2O catalytic decomposition, followed by tetrahedral Co2+ and the Co3+, and Co2+ Ⅰ shows the lowest activity. 3.3 Reaction mechanism The reaction mechanism (Fig. 11 ) of N2O decomposition on cobalt spinel is deemed to an electron transfer process from Co2+ to the anti-bonding orbital of N2O. The NO bond is weakened and broke, resulting in the formation of N2 and Co3+-O−[Eq. (1)]. Further the diffusion of oxygen species (Co3+-O−) and final recombination into an O2 molecule happens, and Co2+ is regenerated at the same time (Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism), completing the catalytic cycle [Eq. (2)] [51,52]. Alternatively, O2 may also be generated via a non-diffusive route through a Eley-Ridel mechanism, namely, Co3+-O- could combine with N2O to generate O2, N2, and Co2+ [Eq. (2’)], finishing the catalytic cycle [53,54]. According to the reaction mechanism, it is obvious that the electron-donating ability of Co2+, the diffusion of oxygen species and the O2 desorption capacity are important to N2O decomposition. 3.3.1 The first step: N2O activation Compared to Co2+Td of impregnated Co/HAP catalysts, XPS results indicate that Co2+ ⅡOh of the Co(1.2)-IE is more electron-rich. At the same time, the Co2+ ⅡOh substituted for Ca2+ Ⅱ is difficultly reduced (H2-TPR). In other words, Co2+ ⅡOh has a lower ability to get electrons, indicating that the oxidation ability of Co2+ ⅡOh becomes weaker. In general, the weaker the oxidation ability of a species, the stronger reducibility is [7–10]. Meanwhile, Wang et al. [55] confirm that octahedron-coordinated Co2+ sites (Co2+Oh) are more likely oxidized to Co3+ species compared to Co2+Td according to the XPS results. So, the promoted electron donation ability of Co2+ ⅡOh can effectively enhance the activation of N2O. Besides, Co2+ Ⅰ in Co(7.0)-HT also possesses high electron-rich property, but it shows the lowest catalytic activity. It may be due to its location in a narrow channel, which is adverse to make Co2+ Ⅰ accessible to N2O [40]. Further, the ligand field theory is used to explain the geometrical structural factors that the octahedral coordination Co2+ is easily oxidized. For the Co(1.2)-IE, although the coordination environment of Co2+ ⅡOh is an approximate octahedron composed of five O and one OH, the electron-donating ability of Co2+ ⅡOh to Co3+ ⅡOh could also be interpreted via the ligand field theory [55–57]. Fig. 12 gives the schemes of crystal field splitting and electron distribution about Co2+ and Co3+. For the Co2+(d7) electrons states, due to the difference of splitting energy (△) and the electron pairing energy (P), it is decided to adopt high-spinning or low-spinning. Co2+ on the octahedral site is deemed to be low-spinning, because the splitting energy of octahedral field value (△o) for Co2+ is greater than the P [55]. However, Co2+ on the tetrahedral site is only high-spinning because the splitting energy of tetrahedral field value (△t) is much smaller than the P [56,57]. The crystal-field stabilization energies (CFSE) of Co2+ on octahedral and tetrahedral sites are 6*0.4△o‒1*0.6△o‒P = 1.8△o‒P and 4*0.6△t‒3*0.4△t = 1.2△t, respectively. The CFSE of Co3+ on octahedral and tetrahedral sites are 6*0.4△o‒2P = 2.4△o‒2 P and 3*0.6△t‒3*0.4△t = 0.6△t. As we all know, the value of CFSE represents the stability of the coordination field. The higher the value, the more energy is reduced and more stable for the metal ion. Consequently, the CFSE value of Co3+ Oh (t2 g 6e g 0) is higher than that of Co2+Oh (t2 g 6e g 1) in a moderate ligand field. So, it is easy for Co2+Oh to remove an electron to become Co3+Oh. However, the value of ligand field from Co2+Td (e g 4t2 g 3) to Co3+ Td (e g 3t2 g 3) will decrease, resulting in that the oxidation of Co2+Td to Co3+Td becomes hard. Compared to Co2+(Td), Co2+ Ⅱ(Oh) is more easily oxidized to Co3+, indicating that Co2+ Ⅱ(Oh) is easier to donate electrons than Co2+(Td), which naturally promotes the first step of N2O catalytic decomposition, and it is identical to H2-TPR and XPS results. 3.3.2 The second step: oxygen desorption Generally, the regeneration of active sites via O2 desorption is also considered as the critical step [Eq. (2)] [51,52] for N2O catalytic decomposition. Therefore, it is essential to study the oxygen desorption ability of the active site. To this end, the nearest distance of two Co2+ on some crystal planes of Co3O4 (Here, the easily exposed crystal planes [a:(311) b:(111)] or the theoretically stable crystal plane [c:(100)] is selected) and the nearest distance of two Co2+ ⅡOh in the HAP channel were calculated according to the crystal model showed in Fig. 13 . It can be seen that all the distances between Co2+ are 5.715 Å on the (311), (111), and (100) crystal planes of Co3O4, however, the distances between Co2+ ⅡOh in the HAP channel are 4.214 Å and 4.148 Å, respectively. Interestingly, it is found that no matter which crystal plane is chosen, the distance between Co2+ is always greater than that between Co2+ ⅡOh. As show in Fig. 14 , referring to the bond lengths of CoO (2.282 Å) and O-O (1.2 Å), Co-O species appear to be more favorable for direct collisions at adjacent Co3+ ⅡOh sites (2.282 + 2.282＞4.214). For the larger distance between adjacent Co3+Td (5.715 Å), it suggests that the direct hopping of oxygen species along the adjacent cobalt sites becomes quite difficult, which may need to be combined by indirect diffusion with more higher energy [58]. Therefore, the closer distance between the active sites may be conducive to the contact and collision of oxygen species, and the spacing effect can facilitate the rate of oxygen desorption, and finally enhance the regeneration of active site. It can be deduced that the closer distance between Co2+ ⅡOh is an another reason for the higher catalytic activity. Furthermore, O2-TPD experiments (Figure S13) were carried out to prove this hypothesis. 3.3.3 DFT calculation DFT calculations about the d-band centers of the samples were carried out to further investigate the origin of the different catalytic performance for N2O decomposition. As we know, the d-band center can be used as a descriptor of catalytic activity [59,60]. A large number of literatures [61,62] have shown that the higher d-band center, the higher catalytic activity of the active site is. As shown in Fig. 15 , the d-band center of Co2+Td in Co3O4 (111 plane) is higher than that of Co3+Oh (100 and 110 plane). Notably, Co2+ ⅡOh of Co(1.2)-IE shows the highest d-band center, which is about 1.5 and 2.3 eV higher than the that of Co2+Td and Co3+Oh, respectively. However, though Co2+ Ⅰ in Co(7.0)-HT also possesses high d-band center, it shows the lowest catalytic activity, which may be due to its location in a narrow channel. 4 Conclusions A series of Co/HAP catalysts prepared using the ion exchange, impregnation and hydrothermal method were tested in N2O catalytic decomposition. The results show that the specific activity of the catalysts follows the sequence: Co(1.2)-IE > Co(1.2)-IM > Co(5.0)-IM > Co(7.0)-HT. For the Co(1.2)-IE, the atom efficiency is high and the value of its specific activity reaches 5.25 μmols−1 g−1, which is 2.84 times higher than that of CoxOy nanoparticles. Deactivation occurs over time for the Co(1.2)-IM, however, Co(1.2)-IE keeps 95 % of N2O conversion over 30 h. In addition, Co(1.2)-IE shows much stronger resistance against 2.0 vol.% O2 or 2.3 vol.% H2O compared to Co(1.2)-IM. Furthermore, the samples were measured by XRD, TEM, N2-physisorption, ICP, FT-IR, UV–vis, CO2-TPD, H2-TPR and XPS. Compared with Co2+Td, Co3+Oh and Co2+ Ⅰ, Co2+ ⅡOh located at octahedral site in the Co(1.2)-IE is more electron-rich and easy to donate electrons, which is proved by the crystal field coordination theory, thus exhibits excellent N2O activation capacity. Furthermore, shorter spacing distances between Co2+ ⅡOh may facilitate the collision of oxygen species, thereby promoting oxygen desorption. All the above mentioned reasons ultimately lead to the enhanced catalytic activity. Finally, active sites about N2O decomposition are further investigated using DFT calculations, and the results show that Co2+ ⅡOh has the highest d-band center, which indicates much higher catalytic activity of the active site. Through in-depth understanding of the relationship between the structural properties and catalytic activity of Co/HAP catalysts, this study can not only clarify the nature of actives for N2O catalytic decomposition, but also provides a new strategy, tuning cobalt oxidation state, coordination environments and active site spacing, to promote catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: Different methods including ion exchange, impregnation and hydrothermal method were used to prepare Co/hydroxyapatite catalysts with various Co species. The catalytic activities for N2O decomposition were studied. It was concluded that Co2+ ⅡOh existed in Co(1.2)-IE prepared by ion exchange is more active than Co2+Td, Co3+Oh and Co2+ Ⅰ obtained by impregnation and hydrothermal methods, respectively. Meanwhile, Co(1.2)-IE shows better stability and stronger resistance against 2.0 vol.% O2 or 2.3 vol.% H2O in the feed gas. The higher catalytic activity of Co2+ ⅡOh is attributed to its octahedral coordination geometrical structure, which make Co2+ ⅡOh tend to donate electrons to activate N2O. Furthermore, the closer spacing distance between two Co2+ ⅡOh sites can facilitate the combination and desorption of oxygen species. The above mentioned reasons ultimately lead to the increased catalytic activity. Finally, the results of density functional theory calculations indicate that the Co2+ ⅡOh possesses the highest d-band center, which means the excellent catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Co/Hydroxyapatite catalysts for N2O catalytic decomposition: Design of well-defined active sites with geometrical and spacing effects
